channel.title: World : NPR
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: For the first time, Iran acknowledges it sent drones to Russia
item.description: The Iranian foreign minister says only a small number were delivered months before the invasion of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
The Iranian foreign minister says only a small number were delivered months before the invasion of Ukraine.

(Image credit: Ukrainian military's Strategic Communications Directorate via AP)
item.dc:creator: Jason Beaubien

item.title: Millions of Ukrainians left without electricity after Russian strikes
item.description: Millions of Ukrainians are without electricity after Russian strikes and a major battle is brewing over the port city of Kherson.
item.content:encoded: Millions of Ukrainians are without electricity after Russian strikes and a major battle is brewing over the port city of Kherson.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Saudi Arabia cracks down on dissidents living abroad
item.description: NPR's Scott Simon talks with Ellen Knickmeyer of the Associated Press about Saudi Arabia's crackdown on dissidents living abroad.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Simon talks with Ellen Knickmeyer of the Associated Press about Saudi Arabia's crackdown on dissidents living abroad.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: North Korea launches four more missiles as U.S. flies bombers over South
item.description: North Korea launched four ballistic missiles into the sea, as the U.S sent two bombers over South Korea in a dueling display of military might that underscored rising tensions in the region.
item.content:encoded:
North Korea launched four ballistic missiles into the sea, as the U.S sent two bombers over South Korea in a dueling display of military might that underscored rising tensions in the region.

(Image credit: South Korea Defense Ministry via AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Photos: A close-up look at Ukraine grain export inspections
item.description: At the heart of the Ukraine grain export deal is a complex inspection process involving Turkey and the U.N. NPR recently joined a team of inspectors aboard a ship carrying grain in the Marmara sea.
item.content:encoded:
At the heart of the Ukraine grain export deal is a complex inspection process involving Turkey and the U.N. NPR recently joined a team of inspectors aboard a ship carrying grain in the Marmara sea.

(Image credit: Danielle Villasana for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Villasana

item.title: South Africa's transition from coal could be a model for other countries
item.description: A plan for Western countries to help fund South Africa's transition from coal was difficult to reach, but parties announced an agreement Friday. It could be a model for other countries.
item.content:encoded: A plan for Western countries to help fund South Africa's transition from coal was difficult to reach, but parties announced an agreement Friday. It could be a model for other countries.
item.dc:creator: Reid Frazier

item.title: Itaewon residents share how they are feeling after Halloween's tragic crowd surge
item.description: How residents in the Itaewon area in Seoul, South Korea are feeling right now, and how Halloween's tragic crowd surge might affect the "party mecca of South Korea."
item.content:encoded: How residents in the Itaewon area in Seoul, South Korea are feeling right now, and how Halloween's tragic crowd surge might affect the "party mecca of South Korea."
item.dc:creator: Raquel Maria Dillon

item.title: Russia's invasion has prompted Biden to offer reconciliation to Venezuela's president
item.description: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has prompted the Biden administration to extend an olive branch to Venezuela President Nicol√°s Maduro.
item.content:encoded: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has prompted the Biden administration to extend an olive branch to Venezuela President Nicol√°s Maduro.
item.dc:creator: John Otis

item.title: Turkey could use a new law, purporting to combat disinformation, to silence dissent
item.description: A new law purporting to combat disinformation could be used by Turkey to silence dissent.
item.content:encoded: A new law purporting to combat disinformation could be used by Turkey to silence dissent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kenyon

item.title: Reporter's notebook: Haiti's at a breaking point but few want foreign intervention
item.description: The U.S. and other countries put sanctions on Haitian gangsters and a corrupt politician. But as Haiti combats hunger, cholera and gangs, many want Haitian solutions ‚Äî not a foreign troop deployment.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. and other countries put sanctions on Haitian gangsters and a corrupt politician. But as Haiti combats hunger, cholera and gangs, many want Haitian solutions ‚Äî not a foreign troop deployment.

(Image credit: Odelyn Joseph for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: Iran marks the 1979 U.S. Embassy takeover amid nationwide protests
item.description: The country's theocracy, which came to power 43 years ago, faces one of its stiffest challenges amid weeks of widespread protests after the death of a woman arrested by the country's morality police.
item.content:encoded:
The country's theocracy, which came to power 43 years ago, faces one of its stiffest challenges amid weeks of widespread protests after the death of a woman arrested by the country's morality police.

(Image credit: Vahid Salemi/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: African scientists say Western aid to fight pandemic is backfiring. Here's their plan
item.description: Monkeypox is the latest case of how global health inequities persist. Vaccines went to the rich world while Africa lacks access. African scientists call for a bold plan to protect against pathogens.
item.content:encoded:
Monkeypox is the latest case of how global health inequities persist. Vaccines went to the rich world while Africa lacks access. African scientists call for a bold plan to protect against pathogens.

(Image credit: Tommy Trenchard for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj

item.title: Scholz and Xi agree Russia would cross a line with nuclear weapons in Ukraine
item.description: After a meeting with Xi in Beijing, Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz said the two leaders agreed that with the use of nuclear weapons, Russia would cross a line drawn by the international community.
item.content:encoded:
After a meeting with Xi in Beijing, Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz said the two leaders agreed that with the use of nuclear weapons, Russia would cross a line drawn by the international community.

(Image credit: Kay Nietfeld/Pool/AFP/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: War fallout and aid demands are overshadowing the climate talks in Egypt
item.description: War in Ukraine, rising energy and food prices, and growing enmity between the West on the one hand and Russia and China on the other make finding cooperation at the coming climate talks difficult.
item.content:encoded:
War in Ukraine, rising energy and food prices, and growing enmity between the West on the one hand and Russia and China on the other make finding cooperation at the coming climate talks difficult.

(Image credit: Michael Probst/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Haitian-Canadian author Myriam J.A. Chancy makes a reading list for Haiti
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Haitian-Canadian author Myriam J.A. Chancy about what's happening in Haiti and a list of books to help make sense of precipitating events.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Haitian-Canadian author Myriam J.A. Chancy about what's happening in Haiti and a list of books to help make sense of precipitating events.
item.dc:creator: Jason Fuller
